↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I could, but something I was wondering is: why not share the codebase between the webapp and the mobile app so that such discrepancies are minimized? ↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Like, check it out. That link to DRY? It doesn't render as a link in the webapp. However, it does render as a link, and works fine, in Goryon. I've seen before that Markdown tables render fine in Goryon but not in the webapp. They ought to behave as similarly as possible, right? So just in this small interaction there are three discrepancies between how the mobile app and webapp render Markdown.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci Could you please file a bug for @xuu@txt.sour.is to look at, this smells like a bug in the go.yarn.social/lextwt parser ü§î

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @prologic I could, but something I was wondering is: why not share the codebase between the webapp and the mobile app so that such discrepancies are minimized? Otherwise there's parallel development going on at all times, which violates the [DRY](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Don'trepeatyourself?useskin=vector) principle.

@abucci@anthony.buc.ci This is quite hard to do really. Because the ‚Äúweb app‚Äù is a server-side rendered (SSR) app. Mobiles Apps are not normally written this way (in fact they never are). They are two very different code-bases, which is why we spend a lot of effort on the client and the API. On a side note, I‚Äôm also working in parallel on a way to ‚Äúembed‚Äù Go code (as a client) in a Flutter App in the hopes for more reusability for Salty.im ‚Äì If we can pull that off, it‚Äôll also help improve the reuseability of client features and improve on keeping things DRY for the Yarn.social app üëå
